instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
My <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2014 model logic board is not turning on , but fan is running with full speed , no display, no chime sound, Here is the voltage details.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.75V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.350 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5.057V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - this rail is not stable , it's coming and going every 2 sec approx. Not sure it is normal behavior or not. 

I haven't measured other rails , 

could you someone please give a hint where I should start ...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

If fan spins, board turns on.
Not working properly, of course.

Any history available?
Check voltage at all big coils.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
I have measured all the inductor values, Unfortunately, I do not know the history of this board, This board was full death, 
I have just cleaned the full board and found some corrosion on <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> (1.05V PCH HSIO Switch), Just applied some solder on it (Attaching some pictures of the board). I don't know why some of these rails are not stable, Or it is something expected?

L7630 - <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_REG</SIGNAL> - 1.057V
L7310 & L7320 - =<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL> - 1.701 
L7430 - <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> - Not consistent ,coming and going every 2 sec approx
LL7710 -  <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 0V  
L3095 - <SIGNAL>TBTBST_BOOST</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT_REG</SIGNAL> - 0V
L7520 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> - Not consistent, coming and going every 2 sec approx
L7130 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.59V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
You didn't mention any fluctuation at L7630 and L7310/20.
This is not possible, if L7430 and L7520 fluctuate.

Is your board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

Try to start in SMC bypass, just for test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: Yes just measured again, Now I can see the fluctuation in these rails too, I am new to this forum and MacBook board repair, Could you explain how I can bypass the SMC? and where I can find the board serial number?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Check under SSD for board code.

Google could help you too...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: I have followed the SMC bypass steps. Now fan is running every 2second once. Voltage is still fluctuating.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: For <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, board code should be near the right speaker connector.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
Dear, 
Board serial number is 820 -3476-A, I am confused about where should I look for solving this voltage fluctuation. Could you give a clue? While bypassing SMC also I have voltage fluctuation And the fan running in the same sequence as other rails, Probably fan supply voltage also fluctuating. Is It a sensing issue? What are the possibilities?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
SMC bypass disables sensing, so there is other problem.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS stable for sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: Yes both <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are 3.348V & those are not fluctuating its stable

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: Do you get any pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message: I don't have an oscilloscope, Measured <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> by using a multimeter I can see a 0.3V is coming and going every second on  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. This means that there is some pulse is coming, But it is not stable

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
An o-scope is not really needed.
The pulse should appear each time fan spins.
Usually getting higher peak value, not only 0.3V.

Check if all output voltages from pages 59 & 60 try to appear.
If not, check diode mode to ground on that rail.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
I have measured page 59 and page 60 , 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.027V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating

page 59 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C3287</CAPACITOR> - 3.349V - stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7841</CAPACITOR> - 1.035V stable 

page 60
1.5V S0 Audio Switch - fluctuating 
3.3V S4 Switch - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_FET_R</SIGNAL> - fluctuating 
3.3V S3 Switch - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_FET_R</SIGNAL> - fluctuating 
3.3V S0 Switch - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - fluctuating 
3.3V Sensor Switch - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS_FET_R</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating
5V S0 Switch - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating
3.3V SSD Switch - at <RESISTOR>R5580</RESISTOR> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FET</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating
3.3V SUS Switch - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET_R</SIGNAL> - 3.348V stable   
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - No voltage (maybe because <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> is not equipped ???)
1.05V PCH HSIO Switch - <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> - Fluctuating

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
Probably more areas affected by corrosion, especially BGA chips.
Reball SMC, as next step.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
Looking at the microscope I couldn't see corrosion around SMC. Could you please educate me how is your attention went to SMC?
I was under the impression that one of the power rail /power good is failing ---> due to that SMC is shutting down the entire power supply enable signals ---> then SMC trying again with new enable after some time --- > again it's fail due to a bad pgood.

please correct me if I am wrong , I may be wrong , I am a power Electronics designer. Normally when we design power converters ,  power goods are monitored and controlled this way. Not sure how it is done in MacBooks.

Does anybody has a pre measured impedance of each power rails . So that I can make sure if any of the power rails are bad.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses, means power on sequence is completed.
This requires presence of all power good signals.

You cannot see corrosion underneath SMC, just reball it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on but fan runs at full speed..
threads.message:
To be honest, I am stuck, I couldn't remove the SMC my resolder station is not capable to offer enough heat or airflow (I have even tried with450 degree celsius and full airflow).
 I think I should buy a new resolder station for BGA's. I have found Louise is recommending QUICK 861DW. To be honest I don't have that much budget. Is there some other solder station which I can afford for a better price?
